comment_text.mn86:2.1: This is a rare sutta where the Buddha’s words take a back seat to dramatic narrative. The reform of the serial killer Aṅgulimāla became one of the most popular stories in Buddhism, with is its message of redemption even for the most wicked. The narrative with extensive backstory has been elaborated in the Pali commentaries and several parallels, with various overlaps and divergences, where events become inflated to an implausible degree. The tendency to exaggeration is found even here, for example in the claim that Aṅgulimāla laid waste to entire countries.
comment_text.mn86:2.3: Aṅgulimāla’s eponymous grotesquerie of a “finger garland” is explained by the commentary and some parallels as being a count of his victims killed by order of his former Brahmanical teacher, who assigned him this task out of jealousy. This unlikely scenario was rejected by Richard Gombrich (How Buddhism Began, pg. 151), who proposed that Aṅgulimāla belonged to a violent cult. The shared core of canonical accounts, however, ascribe no religious motivation to his acts: he is just a killer. He is driven by untrammeled will to power, the need to show he is stronger and better.
comment_text.mn86:3.10: Attha in hatthattha means “death, end” (commentary: atthaṁ vināsaṁ).
comment_text.mn86:4.7: For “like a conqueror” (pasayha maññe) compare how the “fierce-fanged lion, king of beasts” wanders as conqueror at Snp 1.3:38.1. Aṅgulimāla sees the Buddha’s strength as a challenge; he needs to prove himself the mightiest.
comment_text.mn86:5.6: The decisive turn comes when Aṅgulimāla must admit he is not the strongest.
comment_text.mn86:6.2: These verses in this sutta are found in Aṅgulimāla’s verses at Thag 16.8.
comment_text.mn86:6.7: This phrase is shared with the Jains, Sūyagaḍa 14.23: savvehi pāṇehi nihāya daṇḍaṁ.
comment_text.mn86:10.5: It is Pasenadi’s duty, not the Buddha’s, to defend his citizens. Yet while the Buddha had already identified the problem, taken action, and solved it, Pasenadi is just now coming to the Buddha to announce his intention to do something about it. A certain criticism of Pasanadi’s weakness can be discerned here.
comment_text.mn86:11.2: As Ajātasattu would for a runaway slave who ordained at DN 2:36.2.
comment_text.mn86:12.12: Gagga is a clan descended from the Vedic seer Garga Bhāradvāja (Rig Veda 6.47). Clan members feature prominently throughout Brahmanical literature (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1, 3.6, 3.8; Praśna Upaniṣad 4, etc.), none of whom, however, share Aṅgulimāla’s depravity. | Mantāṇī, spelled Maitrāyaṇī in Sanskrit (Mahāvastu 3.377, cf. Puṇṇa son of Mantāṇī at MN 24:2.4), is shared with the Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā, the oldest ritual text of the Black Yajurveda.
comment_text.mn86:13.7: This heads off a potential criticism of Buddhism that it would allow criminals to flourish. Non-violent approaches are not just morally superior but more effective.
comment_text.mn86:14.2: Mūḷha here has the sense of “gone astray” in reference to obstructed labor that prevents birth; see Ud 2.8:1.4.
comment_text.mn86:14.4: Kilissanti here has the sense “undergo distress or travail”. Compare garbhakleśa in Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa 22.45 with the sense, “travails of childbirth”.
comment_text.mn86:15.2: The asseveration of truth—the belief that “by this truth” (tena saccena, also at Snp 2.1) effective results could be won—can be traced to Rig Veda 1.21.6 (tena satyena).
comment_text.mn86:15.6: This is still used as a blessing for pregnant women in Theravada. | “Noble birth” is a unique way of referring to ordination. It echoes the upanayana initiation, where the teacher is said to become pregnant with the student and give birth to them as a brahmin (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.4; also see notes to MN 26:15.2 ff.).
comment_text.mn86:17.7: For the residual effects of kamma, compare such suttas as SN 56.49, where for a stream-enterer the suffering that has disappeared is like a great mountain, while that which remains is like seven pebbles. For Aṅgulimāla as an arahant there is even less, but not none at all.
comment_text.mn86:18.26: Creatures “firm and frail” (tasathāvare) is a common Jain idiom. Examples include tasesu thāvaresu ya (Uttarādhyayana 5.8); je keī tasathāvarā (Sūyagaḍa 3.4.20); tasaṁ vā thāvaraṁ vā (Dasaveyāliya 4.1.42); tasa-jīvā ya thāvarattāe (Ācāraṅgasūtra 9.1.14).
comment_text.mn86:18.35: Aṅgulimāla became known as “Harmless” (Ahiṁsaka) after his awakening.

root_text.mn86:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pasenadissa kosalassa vijite coro aṅgulimālo nāma hoti luddo lohitapāṇi hatapahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu.

root_text.mn86:3.1: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn86:3.2: Sāvatthiyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto senāsanaṁ saṁsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena coro aṅgulimālo tenaddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajji.
root_text.mn86:3.3: Addasāsuṁ kho gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino bhagavantaṁ yena coro aṅgulimālo tenaddhānamaggapaṭipannaṁ.
root_text.mn86:3.6: Etasmiṁ, samaṇa, magge coro aṅgulimālo nāma luddo lohitapāṇi hatapahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu.
root_text.mn86:3.7: Tena gāmāpi agāmā katā, nigamāpi anigamā katā, janapadāpi ajanapadā katā.
root_text.mn86:3.8: So manusse vadhitvā vadhitvā aṅgulīnaṁ mālaṁ dhāreti.

root_text.mn86:3.13: tatiyampi kho gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn86:3.14: “mā, samaṇa, etaṁ maggaṁ paṭipajji, etasmiṁ samaṇa magge coro aṅgulimālo nāma luddo lohitapāṇi hatapahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu, tena gāmāpi agāmā katā, nigamāpi anigamā katā, janapadāpi ajanapadā katā.
root_text.mn86:3.15: So manusse vadhitvā vadhitvā aṅgulīnaṁ mālaṁ dhāreti.

root_text.mn86:5.1: Atha kho coro aṅgulimālo asicammaṁ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṁ sannayhitvā bhagavantaṁ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
root_text.mn86:5.2: Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṁ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā coro aṅgulimālo bhagavantaṁ pakatiyā gacchantaṁ sabbathāmena gacchanto na sakkoti sampāpuṇituṁ.
root_text.mn86:5.5: Ahañhi pubbe hatthimpi dhāvantaṁ anupatitvā gaṇhāmi, assampi dhāvantaṁ anupatitvā gaṇhāmi, rathampi dhāvantaṁ anupatitvā gaṇhāmi, migampi dhāvantaṁ anupatitvā gaṇhāmi;
root_text.mn86:5.6: atha ca panāhaṁ imaṁ samaṇaṁ pakatiyā gacchantaṁ sabbathāmena gacchanto na sakkomi sampāpuṇitun”ti.
root_text.mn86:6.1: Atha kho coro aṅgulimālo bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
root_text.mn86:7.1: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmatā aṅgulimālena pacchāsamaṇena yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṁ pakkāmi.
root_text.mn86:7.2: Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena sāvatthi tadavasari.
root_text.mn86:7.3: Tatra sudaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn86:8.1: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pasenadissa kosalassa antepuradvāre mahājanakāyo sannipatitvā uccāsaddo mahāsaddo hoti:
root_text.mn86:8.2: “coro te, deva, vijite aṅgulimālo nāma luddo lohitapāṇi hatapahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu.
root_text.mn86:8.3: Tena gāmāpi agāmā katā, nigamāpi anigamā katā, janapadāpi ajanapadā katā.
root_text.mn86:8.4: So manusse vadhitvā vadhitvā aṅgulīnaṁ mālaṁ dhāreti.
root_text.mn86:9.1: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo pañcamattehi assasatehi sāvatthiyā nikkhami divā divassa.
root_text.mn86:9.3: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho rājānaṁ pasenadiṁ kosalaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:9.4: “kiṁ nu te, mahārāja, rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro kupito vesālikā vā licchavī aññe vā paṭirājāno”ti?
root_text.mn86:10.1: “Na kho me, bhante, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro kupito, nāpi vesālikā licchavī, nāpi aññe paṭirājāno.
root_text.mn86:10.2: Coro me, bhante, vijite aṅgulimālo nāma luddo lohitapāṇi hatapahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu.
root_text.mn86:10.3: Tena gāmāpi agāmā katā, nigamāpi anigamā katā, janapadāpi ajanapadā katā.
root_text.mn86:10.4: So manusse vadhitvā vadhitvā aṅgulīnaṁ mālaṁ dhāreti.
root_text.mn86:11.1: “Sace pana tvaṁ, mahārāja, aṅgulimālaṁ passeyyāsi kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitaṁ, virataṁ pāṇātipātā, virataṁ adinnādānā, virataṁ musāvādā, ekabhattikaṁ, brahmacāriṁ, sīlavantaṁ, kalyāṇadhammaṁ, kinti naṁ kareyyāsī”ti?
root_text.mn86:11.2: “Abhivādeyyāma vā, bhante, paccuṭṭheyyāma vā āsanena vā nimanteyyāma, abhinimanteyyāma vā naṁ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi, dhammikaṁ vā assa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidaheyyāma.
root_text.mn86:11.3: Kuto panassa, bhante, dussīlassa pāpadhammassa evarūpo sīlasaṁyamo bhavissatī”ti?
root_text.mn86:12.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā aṅgulimālo bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti.
root_text.mn86:12.2: Atha kho bhagavā dakkhiṇaṁ bāhuṁ paggahetvā rājānaṁ pasenadiṁ kosalaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:12.4: Atha kho rañño pasenadissa kosalassa ahudeva bhayaṁ, ahu chambhitattaṁ, ahu lomahaṁso.
root_text.mn86:12.5: Atha kho bhagavā rājānaṁ pasenadiṁ kosalaṁ bhītaṁ saṁviggaṁ lomahaṭṭhajātaṁ viditvā rājānaṁ pasenadiṁ kosalaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:12.6: “mā bhāyi, mahārāja, natthi te ito bhayan”ti.
root_text.mn86:12.7: Atha kho rañño pasenadissa kosalassa yaṁ ahosi bhayaṁ vā chambhitattaṁ vā lomahaṁso vā so paṭippassambhi.
root_text.mn86:12.8: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yenāyasmā aṅgulimālo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ aṅgulimālaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:13.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā aṅgulimālo āraññiko hoti piṇḍapātiko paṁsukūliko tecīvariko.
root_text.mn86:13.2: Atha kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo rājānaṁ pasenadiṁ kosalaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:13.4: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:13.6: Yāvañcidaṁ, bhante, bhagavā adantānaṁ dametā, asantānaṁ sametā, aparinibbutānaṁ parinibbāpetā.
root_text.mn86:13.7: Yañhi mayaṁ, bhante, nāsakkhimhā daṇḍenapi satthenapi dametuṁ so bhagavatā adaṇḍena asattheneva danto.
root_text.mn86:13.8: Handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bhante, gacchāma;
root_text.mn86:13.11: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn86:14.1: Atha kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiyaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn86:14.2: Addasā kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo sāvatthiyaṁ sapadānaṁ piṇḍāya caramāno aññataraṁ itthiṁ mūḷhagabbhaṁ vighātagabbhaṁ.
root_text.mn86:14.6: Atha kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo sāvatthiyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:14.7: “idhāhaṁ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisiṁ.
root_text.mn86:14.8: Addasaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, sāvatthiyaṁ sapadānaṁ piṇḍāya caramāno aññataraṁ itthiṁ mūḷhagabbhaṁ vighātagabbhaṁ.

root_text.mn86:15.1: “Tena hi tvaṁ, aṅgulimāla, yena sā itthī tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ itthiṁ evaṁ vadehi:
root_text.mn86:15.2: ‘yatohaṁ, bhagini, jāto nābhijānāmi sañcicca pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropetā, tena saccena sotthi te hotu, sotthi gabbhassā’”ti.
root_text.mn86:15.3: “So hi nūna me, bhante, sampajānamusāvādo bhavissati.
root_text.mn86:15.4: Mayā hi, bhante, bahū sañcicca pāṇā jīvitā voropitā”ti.
root_text.mn86:15.5: “Tena hi tvaṁ, aṅgulimāla, yena sā itthī tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ itthiṁ evaṁ vadehi:
root_text.mn86:15.6: ‘yatohaṁ, bhagini, ariyāya jātiyā jāto, nābhijānāmi sañcicca pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropetā, tena saccena sotthi te hotu, sotthi gabbhassā’”ti.
root_text.mn86:15.7: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo bhagavato paṭissutvā yena sā itthī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ itthiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn86:15.8: “yatohaṁ, bhagini, ariyāya jātiyā jāto, nābhijānāmi sañcicca pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropetā, tena saccena sotthi te hotu, sotthi gabbhassā”ti.
root_text.mn86:15.9: Atha khvāssā itthiyā sotthi ahosi, sotthi gabbhassa.
root_text.mn86:16.1: Atha kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.mn86:16.2: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.mn86:16.3: Aññataro kho panāyasmā aṅgulimālo arahataṁ ahosi.
root_text.mn86:17.1: Atha kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn86:17.2: Tena kho pana samayena aññenapi leḍḍu khitto āyasmato aṅgulimālassa kāye nipatati, aññenapi daṇḍo khitto āyasmato aṅgulimālassa kāye nipatati, aññenapi sakkharā khittā āyasmato aṅgulimālassa kāye nipatati.
root_text.mn86:17.3: Atha kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo bhinnena sīsena, lohitena gaḷantena, bhinnena pattena, vipphālitāya saṅghāṭiyā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn86:17.4: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ aṅgulimālaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn86:17.7: Yassa kho tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, kammassa vipākena bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni niraye pacceyyāsi tassa tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, kammassa vipākaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme paṭisaṁvedesī”ti.
root_text.mn86:18.1: Atha kho āyasmā aṅgulimālo rahogato paṭisallīno vimuttisukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedi;
root_text.mn86:18.17: Disā hi me te manujā bhajantu,
root_text.mn86:18.23: Na hi jātu so mamaṁ hiṁse,

translation_text.mn86:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn86:2.1: Now at that time in the realm of King Pasenadi of Kosala there was a bandit named Aṅgulimāla. He was violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
translation_text.mn86:2.2: He laid waste to villages, towns, and countries.
translation_text.mn86:2.3: He was constantly murdering humans, and he wore their fingers as a necklace.
translation_text.mn86:3.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.mn86:3.2: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, he walked down the road that led to Aṅgulimāla.
translation_text.mn86:3.3: The cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and travelers saw him on the road,
translation_text.mn86:3.6: On this road there is a bandit named Aṅgulimāla. He is violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
translation_text.mn86:3.7: He has laid waste to villages, towns, and countries.
translation_text.mn86:3.8: He is constantly murdering humans, and he wears their fingers as a necklace.
translation_text.mn86:3.9: People travel along this road only after banding closely together in groups of ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty.
translation_text.mn86:3.10: Still they meet their end by Aṅgulimāla’s hand.”
translation_text.mn86:3.11: But when they said this, the Buddha went on in silence.
translation_text.mn86:3.13: and a third time, they urged the Buddha to turn back.
translation_text.mn86:4.1: But when they said this, the Buddha went on in silence.
translation_text.mn86:4.2: The bandit Aṅgulimāla saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn86:4.5: People travel along this road only after banding closely together in groups of ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty.
translation_text.mn86:4.6: Still they meet their end by my hand.
translation_text.mn86:4.7: But still this ascetic comes along alone and unaccompanied, like a conqueror.
translation_text.mn86:4.8: Why don’t I take his life?”
translation_text.mn86:5.1: Then Aṅgulimāla donned his sword and shield, fastened his bow and arrows, and followed behind the Buddha.
translation_text.mn86:5.2: But the Buddha used his psychic power to will that Aṅgulimāla could not catch up with him no matter how hard he tried, even though the Buddha kept walking at a normal speed.
translation_text.mn86:5.5: Previously, even when I’ve chased a speeding elephant, horse, chariot or deer, I’ve always caught up with them.
translation_text.mn86:5.6: But I can’t catch up with this ascetic no matter how hard I try, even though he’s walking at a normal speed.”
translation_text.mn86:5.11: “These ascetics who follow the Sakyan speak the truth.
translation_text.mn86:5.12: Yet while walking the ascetic Gotama says:
translation_text.mn86:5.14: Why don’t I ask him about this?”
translation_text.mn86:6.1: Then he addressed the Buddha in verse:
translation_text.mn86:6.3: And I have stopped, but you tell me I’ve not.
translation_text.mn86:6.5: how is it you’ve stopped and I have not?”
translation_text.mn86:6.7: I’ve laid aside violence towards all creatures.
translation_text.mn86:6.8: But you can’t stop yourself <j>from harming living creatures;
translation_text.mn86:6.9: that’s why I’ve stopped, but you have not.”
translation_text.mn86:6.10: “Oh, at long last a renowned great seer,
translation_text.mn86:6.11: an ascetic has followed me into this deep wood.
translation_text.mn86:6.12: Now that I’ve heard your verse on Dhamma,
translation_text.mn86:6.14: With these words, <j>the bandit hurled his sword and weapons
translation_text.mn86:6.15: down a cliff into an abyss.
translation_text.mn86:6.16: He venerated the Holy One’s feet,
translation_text.mn86:6.17: and asked him for the going forth right away.
translation_text.mn86:6.18: Then the Buddha, the compassionate great seer,
translation_text.mn86:6.19: the teacher of the world with its gods,
translation_text.mn86:6.21: And with that he became a monk.
translation_text.mn86:7.1: Then the Buddha set out for Sāvatthī with Venerable Aṅgulimāla as his second monk.
translation_text.mn86:7.2: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sāvatthī,
translation_text.mn86:7.3: where he stayed in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn86:8.1: Now at that time a crowd had gathered by the gate of King Pasenadi’s royal compound making a colossal racket,
translation_text.mn86:8.2: “In your realm, Your Majesty, there is a bandit named Aṅgulimāla. He is violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
translation_text.mn86:8.3: He has laid waste to villages, towns, and countries.
translation_text.mn86:8.4: He is constantly murdering humans, and he wears their fingers as a necklace.
translation_text.mn86:8.5: Your Majesty must put a stop to him!”
translation_text.mn86:9.1: Then King Pasenadi drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day with around five hundred horses,
translation_text.mn86:9.3: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha on foot. He bowed and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn86:9.4: “What is it, great king? Is King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha angry with you, or the Licchavis of Vesālī, or some other opposing ruler?”
translation_text.mn86:10.2: In my realm there is a bandit named Aṅgulimāla. He is violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings. …
translation_text.mn86:10.5: I shall put a stop to him.”
translation_text.mn86:11.1: “But great king, suppose you were to see that Aṅgulimāla had shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and gone forth from the lay life to homelessness. And that he was refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and lying; that he was eating in one part of the day, and was chaste, ethical, and of good character. What would you do to him?”
translation_text.mn86:11.2: “I would bow to him, rise in his presence, or offer him a seat. I’d invite him to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize his lawful guarding and protection.
translation_text.mn86:11.3: But sir, how could such an immoral, evil man ever have such virtue and restraint?”
translation_text.mn86:12.1: Now at that time Venerable Aṅgulimāla was sitting not far from the Buddha.
translation_text.mn86:12.2: Then the Buddha pointed with his right arm and said to the king,
translation_text.mn86:12.4: Then the king became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end.
translation_text.mn86:12.5: Knowing this, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn86:12.6: “Do not fear, great king. You have nothing to fear from him.”
translation_text.mn86:12.7: Then the king’s fear died down.
translation_text.mn86:12.8: Then the king went over to Aṅgulimāla and said,
translation_text.mn86:12.11: “What clans were your father and mother from?”
translation_text.mn86:12.12: “My father was a Gagga, and my mother a Mantāṇī.”
translation_text.mn86:12.13: “Sir, may Master Gagga son of Mantāṇī be happy.
translation_text.mn86:12.14: I’ll make sure that you’re provided with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”
translation_text.mn86:13.1: But at that time Venerable Aṅgulimāla lived in the wilderness, ate only almsfood, and owned just three robes.
translation_text.mn86:13.2: So he said to the king,
translation_text.mn86:13.3: “Enough, great king. My robes are complete.”
translation_text.mn86:13.4: Then the king went back to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn86:13.6: How the Buddha tames those who are wild, pacifies those who are violent, and extinguishes those who are unquenched!
translation_text.mn86:13.7: For I was not able to tame him with the rod and the sword, but the Buddha tamed him without rod or sword.
translation_text.mn86:13.8: Well, now, sir, I must go.
translation_text.mn86:13.9: I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.mn86:13.10: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.mn86:13.11: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn86:14.1: Then Venerable Aṅgulimāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.mn86:14.2: Then as he was wandering indiscriminately for almsfood he saw a woman undergoing a distressing obstructed labor.
translation_text.mn86:14.3: Seeing this, it occurred to him,
translation_text.mn86:14.6: Then after wandering for alms in Sāvatthī, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn86:15.1: “Well then, Aṅgulimāla, go to that woman and say this:
translation_text.mn86:15.2: ‘Ever since I was born, sister, I don’t recall having intentionally taken the life of a living creature. By this truth, may both you and your baby be safe.’”
translation_text.mn86:15.3: “But sir, wouldn’t that be telling a deliberate lie?
translation_text.mn86:15.4: For I have intentionally killed many living creatures.”
translation_text.mn86:15.5: “In that case, Aṅgulimāla, go to that woman and say this:
translation_text.mn86:15.6: ‘Ever since I was born in the noble birth, sister, I don’t recall having intentionally taken the life of a living creature. By this truth, may both you and your baby be safe.’”
translation_text.mn86:15.7: “Yes, sir,” replied Aṅgulimāla. He went to that woman and said:
translation_text.mn86:15.8: “Ever since I was born in the noble birth, sister, I don’t recall having intentionally taken the life of a living creature. By this truth, may both you and your baby be safe.”
translation_text.mn86:15.9: Then that woman was safe, and so was her baby.
translation_text.mn86:16.1: Then Aṅgulimāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn86:16.2: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.mn86:16.3: And Venerable Aṅgulimāla became one of the perfected.
translation_text.mn86:17.1: Then Venerable Aṅgulimāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.mn86:17.2: Now at that time someone threw a stone that hit Aṅgulimāla, someone else threw a stick, and someone else threw gravel.
translation_text.mn86:17.3: Then Aṅgulimāla—with cracked head, bleeding, his bowl broken, and his outer robe torn—went to the Buddha.
translation_text.mn86:17.4: The Buddha saw him coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn86:17.7: You’re experiencing in this very life the result of deeds that might have caused you to be tormented in hell for many years, many hundreds or thousands of years.”
